review_title: Focus  on high volumes over fairness to stakeholders, and staff wellbeing.
pros:
The CEO Charlie Massey appears to be a capable and compassionate man, unfortunately the management below him have no engagement with their staff and disregard his wellbeing initiatives. 
Acceptable pay. 
Nice office in city centre. 
Pension. 
Working from home/flex.
cons:
Sadly the culture of the GMC is rapidly deteriorating to a point where many staff feel the organisation has lost sight of their ethics in favour of how they are perceived.
There is no understanding or concern for wellbeing at a Director/Section level despite this being a focus from the CEO. 
Investigations staff are given unrealistic case targets that the majority cannot hit, and are penalised when they don't succeed 
High pressure environment with frequent meetings to justify performance. 
Senior managers have no understanding of the investigation job and refuse to listen to staff, or even assess what it involves. 
Staff survey results consistently flag that the senior management team refuse to listen to their staff or consultant them about changes year in and year out. 
Systemic wellbeing concerns are ignored in favour of free access to meditation apps. 
Concerns about dangerous processes that affect patient safety are routinely ignored in favour of closing cases quickly to please external stakeholders.
The GMC's current trajectory is to close more and more cases without action in favour of local investigation disregarding the risk raised by numerous hospital scandals.

review_title: Some bright spots but not enough to make this a good workplace
pros: Among its more established teams there is a good team atmosphere and collaboration is enjoyable when you are doing stimulating or challenging work, which is sometimes of international significance. The GMC has a good reputation and some of its work is rigorous and interesting. The London location is good; I can't speak for the accessibility of the Manchester or other UK offices but certainly the Manchester site is really nice inside and seems to be situated in a great spot for workers.
cons: The middle management is overstuffed, stifles innovation and generates paranoia. Performance results are adjusted to suit the expected range, so if your manager has not successfully fought--or even bothered to fight--for your team, everybody ends up being adjusted down and losing out on pay rises. Middle-to-higher managers are oversecure and underperformance is tolerated with no real opportunity to whistleblow or even give honest feedback. The political environment is so difficult, with both the Department of Health and doctors such powerful voices, that the GMC has little or no impulse to be creative or assertive.

review_title: Still here after eight years, so they must be doing something right
pros:
The work is hard, fast-paced and intellectually challenging but I find that really stimulating. That could be the part of the organisation I work for, though. 

The team around me is one of the best I've ever worked with.
cons:
GMC is a large corporate organisation - over 1,000 staff in total - operating in a complex legal and political environment. This affects the way the organisation works. Decisions are made carefully and this can lead to some slowness and aversion to risk which is perfectly understandable given the politicised nature of the medical profession. To be fair the organisation knows this and is trying to do something about it.

Organisation is going through a large change programme at the moment. As part of this it's  relocating a number of roles from London to Manchester. A lot of staff are affected, some in my team, and as you'd expect morale has taken a dip.

review_title: Like watching paint dry. Too bureaucratic. Twenty Twelve for the medical profession.

Change programme yet they are losing all the good people and keeping the dross that are waiting to retire that add very little value. Old boys club still. Bring a female CEO in. A sinking ship.

review_title: Sucks the life out of you.
pros:
- Flexible working (one day a week at home in most teams)
- Subsidised private health insurance and checks
- Superannuated pension scheme
- Pays above industry standard (for a reason)
- London office has an amazing location. 2 mins from TCR, 2 mins from Regents Park, 5 mins from Goodge Street and 10 mins from Oxford street. 
- Catering at the London office events is delicious. Hats off to the head chef, his desserts are to die for!
cons:
- Office culture: The first thing which will strike you about the GMC, is that everyone is so nice! But that's until you have settled in and you begin to notice not the cracks, but craters among the staff. There are 3 types of people who work at the GMC: (1) Fake, will do absolutely anything to get to know the right people, teamwork takes a backseat if they can push themselves forward, generally cause a lot of noise and fuss about work which can be completed calmly in a methodical way- but that doesn't attract attention right? (2) Real, these people work hard at what they do, they get things done and generally think wtf at the type 1s and culture. They find it amusing to watch type 1's behaviour and will seek to leave asap because they are overworked, under appreciated and receive near enough 0 job satisfaction. (3) A job is a job. This type rely on the good wage and benefits that the GMC provide- they sit there 9 to 5 doing what they have to do and leave. Generally people who need to support a family and those who desire job security above all, are in this category. 

- No appreciation and lack of development: You will work late nights, develop great ideas only for verbal praise. Which is great to a point- but what you really want is the chance to develop, you want to try new things and you want to move upwards. This isn't going to happen, unless you're a Type 1. Generally if you are in an admin post, expect to stay there for at least 5 years before you can 'justify' career development, unless of course you sell your soul and adopt Type 1 techniques. Brown nosing anyone? 

- Company culture: The GMC lives in its own world- an ivory tower. It is not in touch with reality. The fabulous internal comms team will carry out numerous staff meetings and away days to gather staff feedback to shape the company strategy. Very few of these ideas are adopted. They carry out an annual 'Valued Awards' show to say thank-you to staff, the nomination process is laborious in itself. Nothing can be light-hearted and simple at the GMC, in order to nominate another team or colleague you will have to justify why they deserve the award by filling out a form against the 5 company values. Really? 

- Old boy organisation- It's exactly like that. You don't talk to senior members of staff, Council members, the CEO, the COO or the Chair... unless they initiate it. You don't even look at senior members of staff, Council members, the CEO, the COO or the Chair... unless they initiate it. But fret not! As most of the time they will walk straight past you like you don't even exist. This is after they will assure you at every staff event that they REALLY want to get to know you.

review_title: If you join us then your well-being will be dependant upon your manager!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: 35 hour week, location, office environment, well-being champions, the overwhelming majority of colleagues are lovely people, facilities, Learning and Development courses, secondment opportunities, annual staff medical (please note this is a benefit in kind). The people make it!
cons: A small number of people break it! There are some individuals in Fitness to Practise who are totally immersed in a blame culture. What this means is that they desperately hunt colleagues to point the finger at. When they're ok then you're fine, if they're not ok then they will let you know (and cc everyone in). During my tenure at the GMC I have been settled, contented, even happy! ... only for someone to take exception. When the resentment takes hold of them, it can feel like the loneliest place on earth. I know that my personal experience isn't unique, thankfully the majority are just like me, trying to do a good job. I wouldn't recommend joining the GMC on the basis that eventually you will be made to feel undervalued, abandoned and disengaged from your employer. If you have the capacity to cope in that situation then come and join us as it will pass in time and you will see some respite before someone takes exception all over again. Many of us quietly withdraw, keep ourselves under the radar and try to detach from the noise of the platoon of crashing ego's. You can actually move teams to avoid conflict but is that really how we should deal with this? Also, my experience of meetings, forums, feedback sessions is that you're invited to give your point of view, then almost instantly a random colleague, a manager or even the facilitator will make you feel invalid. It can be quite entertaining when you become aware of it and its often the reason why very few colleagues will respond to an invitation to share their views/feelings, whereupon the silence can be deafening.
